bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 15, 1900

div1.p: Lazear describes his domestic arrangements in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 15, 1900
div1.opener:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE. Feb 15 1900
My dear Mother,-
div1.p:
I was glad to get your two
letters and I am just as well pleased
that the boxes did not come as I
find that many of the things would be
of no use to us here I am going to
ask you to have the boxes opened and
some of the things sent to the storage
warehouse. Rather an imposition on you
but it would be a great favor. The small
box need not be opened. It contains only
scientific apparatus, a list of which I
shall enclose. I shall also enclose
a list of things in the other boxes which
we shall need and another list of
things to be sent to the warehouse
If I have forgotten anything use your
own judgment about sending and if
in doubt send it. I think the square
box would do for the things to be
sent but if not you could get a
strong box somewhere in the neighborhood.
Please send the two boxes by the Southern
Express instead of by freight. I find that
the difference in cost is not great and
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
that by freight it would take at least
a month to reach here. Please
get Snyder to mark the address
slowly on the boxes.

We are at last settled in our quarter
we have two frame houses of one room
each connected by a short bridge.
One of the rooms is very large and
we are going to curtain one and off as
a bed-room for Mabel and me and
use the rest as a sitting room. The
other room is for the baby and Gertrude.
The houses are of plain pine boards
without any trimming. There are no
glass windows, only shutters but we
would have no use for windows.
We are on high ground and there is
a breeze blowing constantly. The medical
staff is all close together and we
shall mess with them. There is one
other lady the wife of the post-surgeon
The baby is getting along nicely. Milk is
impossible to get but we have condensed
milk and we are giving him eggs and
oat meal and meat juice which
he takes to very kindly. They have all
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
been very kind here. We have the use
of four hospital beds and they have
would as mosquito nets until our
arrive. We bought three chairs and
a few pans and things. It is lucky
we did not have to buy much as
everything is frightfully dear. Most
things are about ten times as much
as at home.

I am delighted to find the laboratory very
well equipped and they are ready to get
whatever I may need.

It has been very warm until today but
now it is very pleasant and cool.

I wish I had a Kodak to give
you some views of our surroundings
but I shall try to get a photographer
to come out and take some
pictures.
div1.closer:
Your affectionate Son.
